name: DFT for Superconductor Tc Prediction
brief: Density functional theory calculations to predict critical temperature of superconducting materials.
long_description: DFT combined with electron-phonon coupling calculations (DFPT, EPW) to predict Tc. McMillan-Allen-Dynes formula relates Tc to electron-phonon coupling constant λ and phonon frequency ωlog. Accuracy limited by functional choice and phonon anharmonicity. Used to screen Q-SMEC superconducting materials. Requires: optimized structure, phonon dispersion, Eliashberg function.
strengths: Predictive before synthesis; identifies promising materials; physical insight into pairing mechanism.
limitations: Accuracy ~50K for Tc; misses exotic pairing; expensive for large systems; functional dependence.
typical_use_cases: Screening superconducting materials, understanding pairing mechanisms, guiding synthesis.

name: Electronic Band Structure Calculation
brief: DFT calculation of energy bands and density of states for crystalline materials.
long_description: Band structure reveals electronic properties: band gap, effective mass, density of states, Fermi surface. Critical for understanding conductivity, optical properties, and thermoelectrics. Q-SMEC uses band structure to optimize: superconductors (DOS at Fermi level), thermoelectrics (Seebeck coefficient), metamaterials (plasma frequency). Methods: DFT with PBE/HSE functionals, GW for accurate gaps.
strengths: Reveals electronic structure; predictive for properties; widely validated.
limitations: Band gap underestimated with standard functionals; expensive GW corrections; no strong correlation.
typical_use_cases: Material characterization, property prediction, semiconductor design, thermoelectric optimization.

name: Boltzmann Transport for Thermoelectrics
brief: Semi-classical Boltzmann transport theory to calculate thermoelectric properties from band structure.
long_description: BoltzTraP solves Boltzmann transport equation using DFT band structure to predict: Seebeck coefficient (S), electrical conductivity (σ), thermal conductivity (κe), power factor (S²σ), and ZT figure of merit. Assumes rigid band approximation and constant relaxation time. Q-SMEC uses to optimize thermoelectric materials for waste heat recovery and solid-state cooling.
strengths: Efficient screening; temperature-dependent properties; doping optimization.
limitations: Constant τ approximation; no phonon transport; inaccurate for strongly correlated systems.
typical_use_cases: Thermoelectric material screening, doping optimization, waste heat recovery design.

name: FDTD for Metamaterial Design
brief: Finite-difference time-domain method for electromagnetic simulation of metamaterials and antennas.
long_description: FDTD solves Maxwell equations on discrete grid in time domain. Enables simulation of: metamaterial unit cells, antennas, THz structures, perfect absorbers, stealth coatings. Q-SMEC uses FDTD to optimize EM properties (ε, μ) for RCS reduction and sensor applications. Requires: geometry, material properties, boundary conditions, excitation. Outputs: S-parameters, absorption, fields, RCS.
complexity: O(N⁴) scaling with grid size and timesteps
strengths: Broadband results; nonlinear materials; arbitrary geometries; physical insight.
limitations: Staircase errors; numerical dispersion; memory intensive; long compute times.
typical_use_cases: Metamaterial design, antenna optimization, RCS reduction, THz device design.

name: THz Time-Domain Spectroscopy
brief: Ultrafast optical technique to measure THz material properties and imaging.
long_description: THz-TDS uses femtosecond laser pulses to generate and detect broadband THz radiation. Measures both amplitude and phase, enabling extraction of complex permittivity and conductivity. Q-SMEC uses THz-TDS to characterize: material properties, sensor response, metamaterial performance. Key components: femtosecond laser, photoconductive antenna or nonlinear crystal, delay stage, lock-in detection.
strengths: Phase-sensitive; broadband (0.1-10 THz); non-contact; material characterization.
limitations: Water vapor absorption; sample thickness requirements; expensive equipment.
typical_use_cases: Material characterization, sensor testing, metamaterial validation, quality control.

name: SQUID Magnetometry
brief: Superconducting quantum interference device for ultra-sensitive magnetic field measurement.
long_description: SQUID consists of superconducting loop with Josephson junctions. Measures magnetic flux quantization with sensitivity <1 fT/√Hz. Q-SMEC SQUIDs enable: MEG (magnetoencephalography), MCG (magnetocardiography), mineral exploration, submarine detection. Operates in shielded environment at cryogenic temperatures (4K or 77K). Gradiometer configurations reject common-mode noise.
strengths: Unmatched sensitivity; DC to kHz bandwidth; quantum-limited detection.
limitations: Cryogenic operation; shielding required; expensive; flux trapping issues.
typical_use_cases: Biomagnetic imaging, geophysics, NDE, materials characterization, fundamental physics.

name: Multi-Objective Sensor Optimization
brief: Computational optimization of sensor design for multiple performance metrics (NEP, SNR, FOM, SWAP-C).
long_description: Combines physics-based models, ML surrogate models, and multi-objective optimization (Pareto frontier) to optimize sensor architecture. Q-SMEC optimizes: material stack, geometry, operating temperature, readout electronics. Objectives: minimize NEP, maximize SNR/FOM, minimize SWAP-C. Constraints: manufacturability, cost, reliability. Methods: genetic algorithms, Bayesian optimization, gradient-based.
complexity: Varies with model complexity and design space size
strengths: Systematic exploration; multi-objective balancing; identifies non-obvious solutions.
limitations: Requires accurate models; computationally expensive; validation needed.
typical_use_cases: Sensor design, trade studies, technology selection, performance prediction.

name: Physical Unclonable Function (PUF) Characterization
brief: Statistical analysis of PUF responses for uniqueness, reliability, and security metrics.
long_description: PUFs exploit manufacturing variations to generate unique device fingerprints. Q-SMEC quantum PUFs use superconducting and quantum material variations. Metrics: inter-device uniqueness (Hamming distance ~50%), intra-device reliability (>99%), entropy rate (bits per challenge), resistance to modeling attacks. Characterization requires: environmental testing (-40 to 85°C), aging tests, statistical analysis of challenge-response pairs (CRPs).
strengths: Quantifies security; identifies weak devices; validates design.
limitations: Requires many devices; time-consuming; aging effects.
typical_use_cases: Security validation, device authentication, anti-counterfeiting, firmware binding.

name: Quantum Key Distribution (QKD)
brief: Quantum protocol for secure key exchange using quantum states (BB84, E91).
long_description: QKD uses quantum mechanics (no-cloning, measurement disturbance) to detect eavesdropping. BB84 protocol uses four polarization states; E91 uses entanglement. Q-SMEC enables QKD through: single-photon sources, quantum detectors, low-loss optical components. Applications: government communications, financial transactions, critical infrastructure. Requires: authenticated classical channel, error correction, privacy amplification.
limitations: Range limited (~100 km fiber); requires quantum hardware; expensive.
typical_use_cases: Secure communications, government/military networks, financial transactions.

name: ML-Based Sensor Fusion
brief: Machine learning algorithms for combining multi-modal sensor data to improve detection and classification.
long_description: Combines data from multiple Q-SMEC sensors (THz, EM, magnetometry, acoustic) using ML for: threat detection, target classification, anomaly detection, predictive maintenance. Methods: Kalman filtering, neural networks, ensemble learning, deep learning (CNNs, RNNs). Q-SMEC AI-SCADA integrates sensor fusion for industrial monitoring. Handles: noise, missing data, sensor failures, conflicting information.
complexity: O(N) to O(N²) depending on model
strengths: Improved accuracy; robustness; handles missing data; automated feature extraction.
limitations: Requires training data; black-box models; computational cost; overfitting risk.
typical_use_cases: Target tracking, threat detection, industrial monitoring, medical diagnostics, autonomous vehicles.
